Content: Use the information to answer the question.

:ibox:A student shows her younger brother a globe, which is a small model of Earth. The student explains to her brother how gravity works. She draws a picture of a person. She shows the person standing on Earth. Then, she shows how gravity acts on a person on Earth.
Which diagram shows how gravity acts on a person when the person is standing on Earth?
Use the information to complete the task.

:box:A student shows her younger brother a globe, which is a small model of Earth. The student explains to her brother how gravity works. She draws a picture of a person. She shows the person standing on Earth. Then, she shows how gravity acts on a person on Earth.

The student shows her brother videos of people all over the world. For each video, they put a pin on the globe in the country where people made that video. Then, they look at all the pins and see a pattern of how gravity acts on Earth.
Show the direction in which gravity acts on each person in the model.
problems/NEG5S/media/2a.jpg
Use the information to answer the question.

:box:The student shows her brother videos of people all over the world. For each video, they put a pin on the globe in the country where people made that video. Then, they look at all the pins and see a pattern in how gravity acts on Earth.
The student and her brother show the results of their research.
problems/NEG5S/media/3a.jpg
What is the pattern in this evidence?

A.Choice: The gravitational force is always toward the smallest object.

B.Choice: The gravitational force is always toward the center of Earth.

C.Choice: The gravitational force is always away from the tallest object.

D.Choice: The gravitational force is always away from areas covered by water.

Content: Use the information to answer the question.
:ibox:Next, the student puts a small toy on top of the globe. The toy stays in place. Her brother asks her to put the toy on the bottom of the globe. The toy falls off.
Based on this observation, her brother gets scared that he could fall off Earthâ€™s surface.
Why does the toy fall off the globe?

A.Choice: The toy is plastic instead of metal. If the toy were metal, it would stay on the globe.

B.Choice: The toy is too large compared to the globe. If the toy were the same size as the globe, it would stay in place.

C.Choice: The globe is hollow. Without material in the center, the globe does not have enough gravitational force to hold on to the toy.

D.Choice: The globe is a model of Earth and shows some Earth features. The globe does not have the same gravitational force on objects that Earth has.

Content: Use the information to answer the question.
A science class has a lizard as a class pet. The lizard is not staying warm enough in its habitat.
problems/NEG5S/media/5a.jpg

The students want to design a better habitat to maintain the proper temperature for the lizard. The students want to change the material at the bottom of the habitat to collect more heat from the heat lamp.
Which material should the students select for the bottom of the habitat to BEST help keep the lizard warm?
:box:A science class has a lizard as a class pet. The lizard is not staying warm enough in its habitat. The students want to design a better habitat to maintain the proper temperature for the lizard.
The students want to add a second heat lamp to the habitat. Their teacher shows the students how to make a circuit to light the bulb in the heat lamp.
problems/NEG5S/media/6a.jpg
Next, the teacher shows the students several materials. The teacher states that two of these materials can be used instead of wire in a circuit.
problems/NEG5S/media/6b.jpg
problems/NEG5S/media/6c.jpg
problems/NEG5S/media/6d.jpg
problems/NEG5S/media/6e.jpg
problems/NEG5S/media/6f.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
Which materials will turn on the lightbulb in the circuit? Select TWO materials.
How can the students BEST classify the correct materials from Part A?
The students notice that the heat lamps are not very bright. The students wonder if using a different material in the circuit will make the lamps brighter.

The students decide to test their idea using lightbulbs. The teacher gets some wire, and the students set up two wired circuits with a lightbulb. They test two different materials: a paper clip and a graphite pencil. The drawings show their results.
problems/NEG5S/media/7a.jpg
problems/NEG5S/media/7b.jpg
:ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
What is the BEST conclusion the students can make based on the results of their investigation?

A.Choice: A paper clip is a better conductor than a graphite pencil.

B.Choice: A graphite pencil is a better conductor than a paper clip.

C.Choice: A paper clip and a graphite pencil are both conductors with the same conductive strength.

D.Choice: A paper clip and a graphite pencil are not conductors, so they have no conductive strength.

Content: Which evidence supports the correct answer from Part A?

A.Choice: Both lightbulbs in the circuits do not produce light.

B.Choice: The lightbulb in the circuit with the paper clip is brighter.

C.Choice: The lightbulb in the circuit with the graphite pencil is brighter.

D.Choice: Both lightbulbs in the circuits produce the same brightness of light.

Content: Use the information to answer the question.
:box:The students notice that the heat lamps are not very bright. The students wonder if using a different material in the circuit will make them brighter.
problems/NEG5S/media/8a.jpg
The students can use metal wires and a paper clip to complete the circuit with a lightbulb.
How do these materials complete a circuit so a lightbulb turns on?

A.Choice: The paper clip reduces energy flow between the battery and the lightbulb.

B.Choice: The metal in the wires allows energy to flow between the battery and the lightbulb.

C.Choice: The metal in the wires stops energy from flowing between the battery and the lightbulb.

D.Choice: The paper clip changes state, which causes energy to flow between the battery and the lightbulb.

Content: Use the information to answer the question.
Two students were playing outside. One student looked behind her and saw her shadow.
problems/NEG5S/media/9a.jpg
How is a shadow made?

A.Choice: A shadow is made when there is no light source.

B.Choice: A shadow is made when an object blocks a light source.

C.Choice: A shadow is made when an object is transparent (clear).

D.Choice: A shadow is made when an object blocks another object.

Content: Use the information to complete the task.

:ibox:The students read more information about shadows in books and on the Internet. They wonder if shadows move during the day and if the shadows are always the same length. In one article, the students find information about shadow position and length. They read that as the sun moves from east to west, a personâ€™s shadow moves around too. They also learn that shadows vary in length.
problems/NEG5S/media/10a.jpg

:ibox:When the sun appears low in the sky, about 10Â° above the horizon (sun position C), a personâ€™s shadow is long (shadow position C). It may be 5.67 times as long as the personâ€™s height. When the sun is 45Â° above the horizon (sun position A), a personâ€™s shadow is about the same length as the personâ€™s height (shadow position A). At midday (sun position B), the sun is 90Â° above the horizon, and a personâ€™s shadow is at its shortest (shadow position B).
Explain how shadows move throughout the day. Select the correct choices to complete the sentences.
When the sun is rising, the shadow is pointing :DD-1: .
When the sun is setting, the shadow is pointing :DD-2: .
During the day, the shadow moves :DD-3: to :DD-4: .
Use the table to complete the task.
One student found a table that shows how a shadow changes during the day.
problems/NEG5S/media/11a.jpg
Complete the sentences to provide evidence that supports how shadow movement shows patterns during the day. Select and write the correct choice into each blank. Choices may be used more than once.
Between 8:00 a.m. and :M-1: , the length of the shadow decreases.
From then, until :M-2: , the length of the shadow increases.
Use the information to answer the question.

:ibox:The students read more information about shadows in books and on the Internet. They wonder if shadows move during the day and if the shadows are always the same length. In one article, the students find information about shadow position and length. They read that as the sun moves from east to west, a personâ€™s shadow moves around too. They also learn that shadows vary in length.
problems/NEG5S/media/10a.jpg

:ibox:When the sun appears low in the sky, about 10Â° above the horizon (sun position C), a personâ€™s shadow is long (shadow position C). It may be 5.67 times as long as the personâ€™s height. When the sun is 45Â° above the horizon (sun position A), a personâ€™s shadow is about the same length as the personâ€™s height (shadow position A). At midday (sun position B), the sun is 90Â° above the horizon, and a personâ€™s shadow is at its shortest (shadow position B).
Which statement BEST describes a pattern in shadow movement throughout a day?

A.Choice: A shadow is shortest in the early morning.

B.Choice: A shadow is longest in the late afternoon.

C.Choice: A shadow is shortest when the sun is closest to the horizon and longest when the sun is farthest from the horizon.

D.Choice: A shadow is longest when the sun is closest to the horizon and shortest when the sun is farthest from the horizon.
